text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 1.11.9, Internal Management Documents, Clearing and Approving Internal Management Documents (IMDs).
IRM 1.11.9.1.7, Acronyms - Removed acronyms Labor Relations (LR) and Workforce Relations (WR). Added acronym Labor/Employee Relations & Negotiations (LERN). Reorganized content into a table.

IRM 1.11.9.2, Clearance Process Overview - Added table about steps an author takes prior to clearance, including sending draft IRM to management for veriﬁcation of content. Update to reduce errors in IRM clearance ﬁles. Added paragraph linking to subsection about expedited clearance.
IRM 1.11.9.2.2, Business Unit Clearance Points of Contact - Updated subsection title from Organizational Clearance Points of Contact.

IRM 1.11.9.4, Specialized Reviewers - Removed IRS toll-free numbers from criteria to send draft IRMs to the Office of Taxpayer Correspondence (OTC). Change due to OTC revising guidance that they are no longer responsible for verifying toll-free numbers and the responsibility is on the program office or IRM author. Update incorporates interim guidance memorandum (IGM) RAAS-01-0122-0001, Interim Guidance on Verifying IRS Toll-Free Phone Numbers.
IRM 1.11.9.4.4, Labor/Employee Relations & Negotiations - Updated subsection title from Workforce Relations due to re-organization name change.

IRM 1.11.9.4.6, Office of Taxpayer Correspondence - Removed IRS toll-free numbers as a reason OTC reviews the draft IRM during clearance due to OTC revising their program responsibilities for verifying toll-free numbers. Update incorporates IGM RAAS-01-0122-0001, Interim Guidance on Verifying IRS Toll-Free Phone Numbers.

IRM 1.11.9.10, Final Stages of the Clearance Process - Added to remove comments, accept changes and turn off tracked changes for the ﬁnal XML ﬁle. Update is to ensure necessary ﬁnal steps taken within XML ﬁle.

Editorial changes made throughout the IRM for clarity. Reviewed and updated grammar, plain language, titles, IRM references, IRS organization or organization terminology to business unit and reorganized content.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
This IRM supersedes IRM 1.11.9 dated August 09, 2021. This IRM incorporates interim guidance memorandum RAAS-01-0122-0001, Interim Guidance on Verifying IRS Toll-Free Phone Numbers.
AUDIENCE
The IMD community: IMD authors, IMD/IRM coordinators, their managers, and those responsible for the clearance, review and approval of IMD material.
Clearing and Approving Internal Management Documents (IMDs)
Table of Contents
Program Scope and Objectives
) Purpose: This IRM section contains guidance for clearing internal manage- ment documents (IMDs). Speciﬁcally, IRM

: a. Establishes Servicewide standards and procedures for reviewing and approving a new, revised or obsolete IRM section. b. Provides guidance and information to program owners on approving a revision or issuance of a new or revised IRM section. c. Provides guidance on completing a document clearance request for IRMs, delegation orders and policy statements. d. Contains guidance on incorporating issued interim guidance, delegation orders and policy statements into the IRM and the clearance of these updated IRMs. (

) Audience: These procedures apply to IRS employees responsible for issuing, authoring, reviewing, approving and managing IMDs including: • IRM authors • IMD/IRM coordinators • IRM reviewers • Managers with IMD program responsibilities • Program directors (
) Policy Owner: The Office of Servicewide Policy, Directives and Electronic Resources (SPDER), within Strategy and Business Solutions (SBS) - Research, Applied Analytics and Statistics (RAAS). (

) Program Owner: SPDER within SBS - RAAS is the program office responsible for overseeing the IMD program and providing Servicewide IMD policy and guidance including the IMD clearance process. Each business unit is respon- sible for establishing an internal process for managing their IMDs based upon these Servicewide processes. (
) Contact Information: Contact SPDER in either of the following ways: • Email at SPDER@irs.gov • Website at https://spder.web.irs.gov/officeinfo/contact/ (
) SPDER is responsible for designing, implementing, and setting the Service- wide standards for the clearance (review and approval) of IMDs. See IRM
, IMD Roles and Responsibilities, for information about executive, business unit and program office IMD requirements. (

) By law, federal agencies document, publish and maintain records of policies, authorities, procedures and organizational operations. The IRM is the source IRS operational guidance and information. See IRM
, Authority, for the authorities and legal obligations of IMDs. (

) Clearance documents are official records and there is a requirement to maintain them in the IRS Historical Research Library. Clearance documents are subject to federal records management requirements and National Archives and Records Administration (NARA) as provided in Document
, IRS Records Control Schedules. See the table in IRM
) for legal references. Approving Internal Management Documents page
Clearing and Approving Internal Management Documents (IMDs) 1.11.9
Purpose: This IRM section contains guidance for clearing internal manage- ment documents (IMDs). Speciﬁcally, IRM 1.11.9:

a. Establishes Servicewide standards and procedures for reviewing and approving a new, revised or obsolete IRM section. b. Provides guidance and information to program owners on approving a revision or issuance of a new or revised IRM section. c. Provides guidance on completing a document clearance request for IRMs, delegation orders and policy statements. d. Contains guidance on incorporating issued interim guidance, delegation orders and policy statements into the IRM and the clearance of these updated IRMs.
Audience: These procedures apply to IRS employees responsible for issuing, authoring, reviewing, approving and managing IMDs including:
Internal Management Documents System
Program directors Servicewide oversee IMD administration under their program responsibility, including approval of new or revised IMDs.
SPDER, as the process owner, monitors changes to the IRS’s Servicewide IMD inventory including new, updated and obsolete content.
) Document Clearance Record (DCR) - Document used to obtain and record the review and concurrence from all affected offices and approval from the sponsible program owner; either the Form
, Document Clearance or the IMD Electronic Clearance Tool, see http://spder.web.irs.gov/imd/ eclearance . (
) Editorial Change - A non-substantive revision to correct minor errors and pographical changes. See IRM
, Editorial Update Process, for examples. (
) External Reviewer - Affected business units/program offices outside of the originating business unit. (

) Internal Management Document (IMD) - Official communication which nates policies, authorities, and instructions to IRS officials and employees. IMDs include the IRM, interim guidance, policy statements and delegation orders. (
) Internal Reviewer - Affected organizations/program offices within the originat- ing business unit. (

) Program Director - Member of the Senior Executive Service (SES) or their authorized delegate responsible for program administration including issuance and approval of IMDs. To identify a member of the SES, see IRM
), Approval by Program Director. See Delegation Order
(New), Authori- zation to Approve an Internal Management Document (IMD), for who can authorized delegate. (

) Program Owner - The program office with primary responsibility for establish- ing the process and procedures necessary to implement and manage an program. The program director over this office authorizes and approves new revised IMDs. (
) Originating Business Unit - Business unit who owns the respective IRM section. (
) Reviewer - A subject matter expert responsible for reviewing an IMD on of their program office, area or business unit. (
) Specialized Reviewer - Speciﬁc and identiﬁed program offices (identiﬁed IRM
, Specialized Reviewers) with oversight in a particular area affecting Servicewide operations. (
) Substantive Change - A revision is substantive if the change involves a dural or operational matter. (
) The table lists commonly used acronyms and their deﬁnitions: Acronym Deﬁnition DCR Document Clearance Record FOIA Freedom of Information Act Approving Internal Management Documents page (
) Internal Revenue Manual

The following are the primary IRMs that provide supplementary information involving the clearance process.
Clearing and Approving Internal Management Documents (IMDs) 1.11.9 page

Actions IRM Reference Finalizes draft IRM, including an updated MT and material changes, for review and approval. IRM 1.11.2, Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) Process Sends the draft IRM to their man- agement for veriﬁcation of content. Author may also infor- mally send to other affected stakeholders and SMEs. IRM 1.11.2.7, Conduct an Informal Review
Sends the draft IRM to their man- agement for veriﬁcation of content. Author may also infor- mally send to other affected stakeholders and SMEs. IRM
, Conduct an Informal Review (
) Authors begin the review and approval process using Form
, Document Clearance Record, or the IMD Electronic Clearance Tool at http://spder.web.irs. gov/imd/eclearance . This serves as a control and a record of routing, review and approval. (
) The assigned author of the IMD determines the effect of the proposed on their office and other program offices and forwards the document to offices for their review and comment. (

) Affected program offices review IMDs when new or revised IMD content contains instructions or guidelines that affect their program office. Reviewing offices are responsible for considering the effect of the revisions on their dures. (
) The responsible program director approves IMD changes to ensure the tions are consistent with IRS operational processes and authorities. (
) The IRM must complete clearance within one year of the date clearance initiated or it must be cleared again. (
) The IMD/IRM coordinator is the last review point prior to uploading the IRM publishing. (
) The following are the steps in the IRM clearance process. Detailed descrip-
The responsible program director approves IMD changes to ensure the instruc- tions are consistent with IRS operational processes and authorities.
The following are the steps in the IRM clearance process. Detailed descrip- tions of these topics are in the referenced IRM subsections.

Step Actions IRM Reference 1 Author identiﬁes reviewers. IRM 1.11.9.3, Identifying Reviewers, and IRM 1.11.9.4, Specialized Reviewers 2 Author sends completed Form 2061, Document Clearance Record, or generated IMD Electronic Clearance Tool email to reviewers. IRM 1.11.9.5, Clearance Submission Guidelines
Internal Management Documents System

Step Actions IRM Reference 3 Reviewers comment and provide an as- sessment on changes within 30 days, plus extension up to 15 days. IRM 1.11.9.7, Guidelines for Reviewers 4 Author considers reviewers’ comments and updates the draft IRM as applicable. IRM 1.11.9.8, Responding to Reviewers’ Comments, and IRM 1.11.9.9, Resolving Dis- agreements 5 Program director reviews and approves the new, changed or obsoleted content. IRM 1.11.9.10.1, Approval by Program Director 6 Author forwards the approved IRM to IMD/ IRM coordinator for publishing who conducts ﬁnal review for submission to M&P for publication. IRM 1.11.9.10.2, Final Review by IMD/IRM Coor- dinator 7 Author or IMD/IRM coordinator forwards the IRM clearance package to IRS Histori- cal Research Library for archiving. IRM 1.11.9.10.3, Archiving Clearance Documents page 6 1.11 Internal Management Documents System
) IRM revisions that only involve editorial changes or the incorporation of previ- ously cleared guidance may follow a streamlined clearance. See IRM
, Instances of Streamlined Clearance. (
) The standard
-day clearance time frame may be reduced to meet business or operating needs following IRM
, Expedited Clearance. Streamlined (

) Clearance is abbreviated or streamlined when changes to an IMD are editorial or incorporate documents previously approved and cleared. These types of IRM changes include: • Editorial updates. • Incorporating IG into the IRM. • Incorporating delegation orders and policy statements into IRM
, vicewide Policies and Authorities. (
) The required level of review and signatures on the document clearance record (Form
or IMD Electronic Clearance Tool), at a minimum, include: a. The author’s manager. b. The program director (or documented designee). c. The business unit IMD/IRM coordinator. (
) Follow IRM
, Revise IRM for an Editorial Change, for completing package for publishing. of Editorial (

) The editorial update process allows for a modiﬁed clearance process when IRM updates are strictly to correct format, punctuation, grammatical or other typographical errors in the published IRM. See IRM
, Editorial Update Process, for a detailed list of editorial changes and the rules for preparing IRM XML ﬁle. (
) Editorial changes do not affect the meaning of the content of the IRM. They require minimal review.
The standard 30-day clearance time frame may be reduced to meet business or operating needs following IRM 1.11.9.5.4.1, Expedited Clearance.
The required level of review and signatures on the document clearance record (Form 2061 or IMD Electronic Clearance Tool), at a minimum, include:
Editorial changes do not affect the meaning of the content of the IRM. They
Clearing and Approving Internal Management Documents (IMDs) 1.11.9
) Generally, the author’s manager, the program director, and the IMD/IRM coor- dinator are the only reviewers. Management may require additional levels of review.
) Incorporating Interim Guidance into the IRM (

) An IRM author may use the streamlined clearance process when updating IRM only to incorporate an interim guidance memorandum (IGM) or a Service- wide Electronic Research Program (SERP) IRM Procedural Update (IPU). Note: Incorporate interim guidance (e.g., IGMs or SERP IPUs) into the applicable IRM(s) within two years from issuance or the stated memo expiration date, whichever is earlier. See IRM
, Interim Guidance Process. (
) Follow these guidelines when revising an IRM to incorporate interim guidance (IGMs or IPUs): (IMDs)
page
Generally, the author’s manager, the program director, and the IMD/IRM coor- dinator are the only reviewers. Management may require additional levels of

and clearing IG.
) Incorporating Delegation Orders and Policy Statements into the IRM (
) After approval, signature and issuance of a Servicewide policy statement or delegation order (see IRM
, Servicewide Policy Statement Process and IRM
, Servicewide Delegation Order Process), SPDER incorporates word-for-word content of the delegation order and/or policy statement into
, Servicewide Policy Statements, and IRM

, Servicewide Delegations of Authority, for recordkeeping purposes. The Office of SPDER: a. Incorporates the approved delegation order or policy statement into the applicable IRM through the streamlined clearance process. See IRM
, Editorial Update Process. b. Archives the IMD clearance package in the IRS Historical Library after
Incorporates the approved delegation order or policy statement into the applicable IRM through the streamlined clearance process. See IRM
, Editorial Update Process. Archives the IMD clearance package in the IRS Historical Library after incorporating the contents into the IRM.
Internal Management Documents System
Clearance Contact (

) Each business unit and specialized reviewer designates a clearance contact receive IRM clearance requests from authors. These designated contacts assist in the coordination of IMD clearance for their business unit. View the of clearance points of contact (POCs) at https://spder.web.irs.gov/imd/authors/ IMDClearanc
OCList.aspx . (

) The clearance POC forwards the IRM to affected program offices and/or subject matter experts (SMEs) as identiﬁed by the author based on the material changes in the MT. If the author indicates a speciﬁc reviewer or in the Form
or email, the business unit’s point of contact forwards the IMD to that program office or SME. (
) The business unit clearance POC may consolidate the responses and back to the originator with comments and one assessment depending on internal process. Reviewers (

) Authors send new or revised IMDs to: • Author’s manager. • IMD/IRM coordinator. • Affected program offices within the originating business unit (internal reviewers). • Affected business units/program offices outside of the originating business unit (external reviewers). • Specialized reviewers as identiﬁed in IRM
, Specialized Reviewers. • Employees who use the new or revised procedures. See IRM
, Requesting Employee Feedback. (

) Identify affected program offices: a. If the changes alter another business unit’s or program office’s work processes, procedures, official forms or internal management documents, send to that business unit or office for review and concurrence. Note: A simple reference to a procedure in another IMD does not clearance through the responsible program office. You must the IRM for clearance only if the revision involves a change to other office’s published procedures or processes. b. If another program office owns the changes, or if another office imple- ments or conducts the work, send to that business unit/program office review and concurrence. (

) A reviewer for clearance purposes is a subject matter expert (SME) or manager who is responsible for reviewing the IMD on behalf of their program office or business unit. Internal reviewers are reviewers within the originating business unit. External reviewers are reviewers outside of the originating business unit. Reviewers provide comments on new or revised IMD content that affects their operations. Example: Consider any program office outside of SB/SE an external reviewer the purposes of IMD clearance if SB/SE owns the IRM. (
) When sending your IMD outside of your business unit, always send the
The business unit clearance POC may consolidate the responses and respond back to the originator with comments and one assessment depending on their
Authors send new or revised IMDs to:

Author’s manager. IMD/IRM coordinator. Affected program offices within the originating business unit (internal reviewers). Affected business units/program offices outside of the originating business unit (external reviewers). Specialized reviewers as identiﬁed in IRM
, Specialized Reviewers. Employees who use the new or revised procedures. See IRM
, Requesting Employee Feedback.
Example: Consider any program office outside of SB/SE an external reviewer for the purposes of IMD clearance if SB/SE owns the IRM.
When sending your IMD outside of your business unit, always send the clearance request to the business unit’s IMD clearance POC in addition to the

known reviewer. Do not send duplicate emails to the IMD coordinators and the business unit POC mailbox. To identify the IMD clearance contact in each business unit, check the Business Unit IMD Clearance Points of Contact page at https://spder.web.irs.gov/imd/authors/IMDClearancePOCList.aspx on the SPDER website.

known reviewer. Do not send duplicate emails to the IMD coordinators and business unit POC mailbox. To identify the IMD clearance contact in each business unit, check the Business Unit IMD Clearance Points of Contact page at https://spder.web.irs.gov/imd/authors/IMDClearanc
OCList.aspx on the SPDER website. (
) Contact the IMD/IRM coordinator for help in identifying a SME or contact in a particular program office. (

) Each business unit must make new or revised IRMs available for feedback to employees who use the IRM. Initiate the feedback process at the time of clearance. The time frame for obtaining feedback from employees who use IRM is ﬁve business days. (
) Each business unit determines their own feedback process. Contact your IMD coordinator at https://spder.web.irs.gov/imd/Resources/IMDContacts/ Default.aspx?org=None&role=IMD%
Coordinator for your business unit’s cess on IRM employee feedback. There is no requirement to document em- ployee feedback and review on Form
) The author must include employee feedback comments in the historical IRM ﬁle. (

) Identiﬁed program offices with oversight in a particular area affecting Service- wide IRS operations are specialized reviewers. There is a requirement for review from a specialized reviewer when the material in the IMD contains content within their program office’s oversight, as described below.

When material contains: Then send the IRM to: IRM Subsection Legal matters as described in IRM 1.11.9.4.1, Chief Counsel Chief Counsel via email to IRMClearance@irscounsel.treas.gov IRM 1.11.9.4.1, Chief Counsel Any of the following as described in IRM 1.11.9.4.2, Privacy, Gov- ernmental Liaison and Disclosure: • Content newly designated as official use only (OUO). • Procedures, policies, or instructions relating to the disclosure or potential dis- closure of official information. • Procedures, policies, or instructions relating to privacy or information pro- tection. Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure (PGLD) via email to *PGLD IMD SPOC IRM 1.11.9.4.2, Privacy, Govern- mental Liaison and Disclosure
Internal Management Documents System

When material contains: Then send the IRM to: IRM Subsection Changes to any sections in the following IRM parts: • Part 1 – Organization, Finance, and Management • Part 3 – Submission Pro- cessing • Part 4 – Examining Process • Part 5 – Collecting Process • Part 7 – Rulings and Agreements • Part 8 – Appeals • Part 20 – Penalty and Interest • Part 21 – Customer Account Services • Part 22 – Taxpayer Education and Assistance • Part 25 – Special Topics Exception: Only forward SERP IPUs to TAS for review if the change affects how a member of the public ﬁles, pays, complies with their tax requirements or interacts with the IRS. Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) via email to *TAS IMD SPOC IRM 1.11.9.4.3, Taxpayer Advocate Service Changes to conditions of employ- ment of bargaining unit (BU) employees; and after completing the steps in IRM 1.11.2.5.1.4, IRM Changes Affecting Conditions of Employ- ment of Bargaining Unit Employees Labor/Employee Relations & Negotiations via email to *WRD-Mailbox IRM 1.11.9.4.4, Labor/Employee Relations & Negotiations Any of the following information: • Instructions on developing or revising taxpayer notices or letters. • Guidance on handling erroneous taxpayer corre- spondence. Office of Taxpayer Correspon- dence (OTC) via email to *W&I OTC IMD POC IRM 1.11.9.4.6, Office of Taxpayer Correspondence 1.11 Internal Management Documents System
Clearing and Approving Internal Management Documents (IMDs) 1.11.9

When material contains: Then send the IRM to: IRM Subsection Procedures relating to: • Implementation of new leg- islation affecting tax administration, or • Interactions with Congress or a member of Congress (e.g., a U.S. Representa- tive or a Senator). Legislative Affairs contact. See https://spder.web.irs.gov/imd/authors/IMDClearancePOCList.aspx IRM 1.11.9.4.5, Legislative Affairs Content relating to identity theft Identity Protection - W&I Office of Identity Protection via email to *W&I CAS:AM:IPSO-IDT- IRMs IRM 1.11.9.4.7, Identity Protection
The Office of Chief Counsel reviews IMDs that reference one or more of the following authorities for legal accuracy:
Note: Not all IMDs referencing such authority require review by Chief Counsel.

) Scope of review - Chief Counsel generally reviews the IRM section for legal matters focusing on the substantial changes identiﬁed in either the material changes portion of the draft IRM or in the track change ﬁle submitted. While Chief Counsel does rely on the listing of substantial changes and on the track change ﬁle submitted for review, Chief Counsel also considers whether the authority for legal matters not updated has changed or whether to address legal matters when there is an updated IRM. (
) An author must submit an IMD to Chief Counsel if Chief Counsel requests review the IMD, or if the IMD contains new or revised guidance interpreting authority listed in paragraph (
) above. Additionally, IRMs in the following chapters must be submitted for Chief Counsel review: a. IRM Chapter
, Returns and Documents Analysis b. IRM Chapter
, Error Resolution c. IRM Chapter
, Campus Document Services (except IRM
, Sub- mission Processing Image Control Team (ICT) Correspondence Scanning, and IRM
, Media Transport and Control) d. IRM Chapter
, International Returns and Document Analysis e. IRM Chapter
, International Error Resolution
IRM Chapter
, Returns and Documents Analysis IRM Chapter
, Error Resolution IRM Chapter
, Campus Document Services (except IRM
, Sub- mission Processing Image Control Team (ICT) Correspondence Scanning, and IRM
, Media Transport and Control) IRM Chapter
, International Returns and Document Analysis IRM Chapter
, International Error Resolution

) An author may submit an IMD to Chief Counsel when: • The author wants to verify whether a current interpretation in the IMD valid, or • The author has a speciﬁc question relating to legal matters and the content relates to an authority in paragraph (
) above. (

) An author should not submit an IMD to Chief Counsel if Chief Counsel previ- ously indicated through email the IRM section does not require their review, if the IRM is revised solely for editorial issues, reorganization of content or re- numbering, or is being obsoleted. Additionally, IRMs in the following chapters should not be submitted for Chief Counsel review: a. IRM Chapter
, Resource Guide for Managers (except IRM sections addressing legal matters, e.g., IRM
, Insolvency) b. IRM Part
, Information Technology − all chapters c. IRM Chapter
, Campus Mail and Work Control d. IRM Chapter

, ISRP System Exception: Authors may submit an IRM meeting the above criteria to Chief Counsel for review if there is a speciﬁc question relating to legal matters in the IRM section. The author must articulate the question in the clearance email to Chief Counsel. (

) Send clearance requests to the Chief Counsel IMD clearance contact at IRMClearance@irscounsel.treas.gov . a. Do not “cc” any attorneys or Chief Counsel subject matter experts in the email requesting clearance. If an attorney provided assistance on the vision of a document, indicate the attorney’s name and any Chief Coun- sel case tracking number (interim guidance only) in the body of the email sent to the Chief Counsel IMD clearance contact. If you believe an attor- ney who didn’t provide assistance on the revision should have the docu- ment directed to them for review, please state why so the attorney’s manager may take it into account. b. Do not ﬁll out Part II, block
a, Speciﬁc external reviewers, of Form
for Chief Counsel. Checking “Chief Counsel” in Part II, block
, Specialized Reviewers, is sufficient. (

) Chief Counsel generally does not review or verify the following unless speciﬁ- cally requested: • Cross-references to forms, notices, other IRMs or other documents. • Listing of transaction codes (TC Codes). • Basic disclosure and privacy rules when clearing an IRM through PGLD. • Indexed ﬁgures in IRMs contained in the Internal Revenue Bulletins (IRBs). • Due dates speciﬁed on tax forms. (
) Chief Counsel generally provides comments on an IRM in a Word feedback form. Comments on an interim guidance generally are in a Word feedback form unless comments in track changes are sufficient.

Governmental Disclosure (

) Authors must submit IMDs to Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure (PGLD) for review and clearance if their instructions involve any of the following: a. Disclosure or potential disclosure of official information or data. b. Newly designated official use only (OUO) information. For additional formation, see IRM
, Clearance of Official Use Only Information. c. Privacy or information protection. For additional information, see IRM
, Clearance of Information about Privacy and Information tection. (

) Laws and policies relating to disclosure issues may change over time and sensitivity of content designated OUO may also change. For this reason, re- sponsibility remains with IRM authors and program management to consider when IMD content no longer warrants an OUO designation. Do not send content to PGLD if they reviewed the original designation or if removing the OUO designation. (
) For IMDs containing identity theft content, see IRM
, Identity Protec- tion. If an IMD contains both identity theft and OUO/disclosure content, send the IMD to both the PGLD and the Identity Protection Strategy & Oversight offices. (
) Include a completed Form
, Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclo- sure Checklist for IMD and Training Materials, with the clearance request. Within the Form
identify the IRM subsection number(s) or page number(s) for the content you believe requires PGLD review. (
) Send the clearance request to *PGLD IMD SPOC . Official Use (
) Submit IMDs containing content newly designated as OUO to PGLD for (
) Designate IRM content as OUO following the criteria outlined in IRM
, Designate IRM Content as Official Use Only (OUO). (

) The following examples of IRM content may require designation of OUO: a. Instructions relating to enforcement strategies, tolerances and criteria where public release would lead to a reasonable expectation of harm IRS actions or operations. b. Material where public release would signiﬁcantly impede or nullify IRS actions in carrying out a responsibility or function. c. Data processing information that would result in taxpayers altering their ﬁling practices or avoiding payment of taxes. Note: Generally, do not classify employee contact names and phone numbers OUO. See IRM
, Contact Information. Reminder: You must follow other privacy and security guidance to protect sensitive and Approving Internal Management Documents
page

Disclosure or potential disclosure of official information or data. Newly designated official use only (OUO) information. For additional in- formation, see IRM
, Clearance of Official Use Only Information. Privacy or information protection. For additional information, see IRM
, Clearance of Information about Privacy and Information Pro- tection.
The following examples of IRM content may require designation of OUO:

Instructions relating to enforcement strategies, tolerances and criteria where public release would lead to a reasonable expectation of harm to IRS actions or operations. Material where public release would signiﬁcantly impede or nullify IRS actions in carrying out a responsibility or function. Data processing information that would result in taxpayers altering their ﬁling practices or avoiding payment of taxes.
Note: Generally, do not classify employee contact names and phone numbers as OUO. See IRM 1.11.2.5.5, Contact Information.

Reminder: You must follow other privacy and security guidance to protect sensitive information, whether electronic ﬁles or in paper. Encrypt documents containing sensitive information when sending out via email or saving to a hard drive. See IRM
, Email, and IRM
, Policy and Guidance.

) PGLD is responsible for ensuring consistency in all processes and procedures affecting the way the IRS handles privacy information protected by statute, regulation, executive order, or internal policy. (

Reviewers. (

) TAS reviews IMDs to ensure they protect taxpayer rights as deﬁned by the Taxpayer Bill of Rights and to identify and mitigate IRS practices which might infringe on taxpayer rights or create undue burden to taxpayers. The Taxpayer Bill of Rights is published in Publication
and is available at https://www.irs. gov/forms-pubs/about-publication-
, Your Rights As a Taxpayer. (

) Employees must protect taxpayer rights when creating instructions. This promotes effective tax administration within all business units, helps to build trust and consistency, and improves voluntary compliance. (
) In accordance with IRC
, Commissioner Of Internal Revenue; other officials, the Office of the Taxpayer Advocate identiﬁes and proposes changes in the practices of the IRS to mitigate taxpayer problems. (
) Send the clearance request to *TAS IMD SPOC . (

) Clearing an IMD through the Human Capital Office (HCO), Labor/Employee Relations & Negotiations (LERN) applies to matters involving a change to con- ditions of employment of bargaining unit (BU) employees. Conditions of employment is a term used to refer to personnel policies, practices, and matters impacting a bargaining unit employee’s daily work life, such as work processes/assignments, schedules, overtime, equipment, office space/design, parking, type/placement of office furniture, relocation of an office. Some changes require formal notice and negotiations with the National Treasury Employees Union (NTEU) before implementing the change. See IRM
, Managing Change and Dealing with the Union. (

) Prior to starting clearance, authors must evaluate all new or revised IMDs (e.g., IRMs and non−emergency interim guidance) for potential changes to conditions of employment of BU employees. For IRMs and interim guidance, see IRM
, IRM Changes Affecting Conditions of Employment of Bargaining Unit Employees.
) If management determines clearance through LERN is necessary after tion per IRM
, IRM Changes Affecting Conditions of Employment Bargaining Unit Employees, submit Form
, Document Clearance Record, or IMD Electronic Clearance Tool email to *WRD-Mailbox . Attach Form Notice to National NTEU, if received from Labor Relations Strategy and tiations (LRSN). Affairs (

) Legislative Affairs is responsible for managing the IRS’s relationship with members of Congress and their staff; planning, developing, directing and evaluating the legislative activities of the IRS. (

) When enacted legislation becomes law, affected IRS business units must develop an implementation plan to make program changes required by new legislation requirements. Speciﬁc implementation actions typically include updates. (

) When a new IMD or change to an existing IMD relates to implementing new legislation affecting tax administration, or to official interactions with members of Congress, the IRM author must send the IMD to Legislative Affairs. (
) Send the clearance request to the Legislative Affairs clearance point of at https://spder.web.irs.gov/imd/authors/IMDClearanc
OCList.aspx . Taxpayer (

) The Office of Taxpayer Correspondence (OTC) reviews an IMD when it contains any of the following: • Instructions on developing, revising taxpayer notices or letters. • Guidance on handling erroneous taxpayer correspondence. (
) Send the clearance request to the Office of Taxpayer Correspondence clearance point of contact at *W&I OTC IMD POC . Protection (
) W&I Identity Protection Strategy & Oversight (IPSO) reviews all IMDs with identity theft guidance. (
) Send the clearance request to the clearance point of contact at *W&I CAS:AM:IPSO-IDT-IRMs . Submission (

) This subsection describes the rules and processes for sending an IRM clearance. This subsection discusses: • How to send an IRM for clearance. • Time frames for clearing IRMs. • What documents to send for clearing IRMs, also known as the clearance package. (

) To clear other IMDs see IRM

, Servicewide Delegation Order Process and IRM

) Before submitting an IRM for clearance, an IRM author’s manager must review the revised IRM content. This internal review ensures the revised guidance is accurate, workable and the author’s manager considered the effect on internal program offices, external program offices and employees’ duties. (

) Clearance can be simultaneous or sequential based on the program office’s needs. Typically, send IRMs to the reviewers simultaneously and then forward to the director for approval after considering reviewer’s comments and making any revisions to the IRM. a. Simultaneous Clearance: In simultaneous clearance, the reviewers review the IRM at the same time. Send the clearance package to all reviewers at the same time. b. Sequential Clearance: In sequential clearance, the reviewers complete the review in a certain order. List each reviewer on the clearance document in the order their review must occur. Once the ﬁrst reviewer completes their review, the author then forwards the clearance request the next reviewer, and so on, until every reviewer completes the review. (

) The author or originator forwards the proposed new or revised IRM and clearance documents through email or forwards the generated IMD Electronic Clearance Tool email to the identiﬁed reviewers; affected program offices, spe- cialized reviewers and SMEs. See IRM
, Identifying Reviewers, and IRM

, Documents Sent for Clearance - Clearance Package. a. For affected program offices and specialized reviewers outside of your business unit, use the assigned business unit IMD clearance point of contact listing at https://spder.web.irs.gov/imd/authors/ IMDClearanc

OCList.aspx . The IMD Electronic Clearance Tool provides the email addresses when you select the affected program offices and specialized reviewers outside of your business unit. Include the affected program office or known SME by name in the email to the point of contact. This information is essential to ensure the correct affected pro- gram office reviews your IMD. The business unit IMD clearance point of contact forwards the clearance request to the program office contact or identiﬁed SME. Note: Do not email your IRM directly to a head of office. Heads of office are those executives who directly report to the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, the Deputy Commissioner for Services and En- forcement and the Deputy Commissioner for Operations Support. b. Provide clear instructions in the email and set a deadline for reviewers review and respond. A sample email is available at https://spder.web.irs. gov/imd/authors/clear.aspx . The IMD Electronic Clearance Tool generates an email with instructions for the author to forward. (
) List the procedural changes in sequential order in the MT material changes. (

calendar days to review and provide any comments. Obtain program director approval when the clearance review time is less than
calendar days. See IRM
, Standard Clearance Time Frame, and IRM
, Expedited Clearance. (
) Contact your IMD/IRM coordinator for speciﬁc guidance, as some business units have internal processes on clearing IRMs. Approving Internal Management Documents page (

calendar days. If this is a non-workday, the date is the next business day. (

calendar days. (

Typically, the author requests a speciﬁc method for reviewers to submit comments. The following are the options:

Type of Document Description Within Form 2061, Document Clearance Record Part III, block 13b, contains a comment section for reviewers that opens when “I concur with comments” or “I do not concur; comments required” is selected. IMD Electronic Clearance Tool The tool allows the addition of comments and, if needed, documents attached. See http://spder.web.irs.gov/imd/eclearance . Comment Form or Matrix A Word or Excel ﬁle in a table format with headings for: • Reviewer name • IRM subsection or other identifying information • Comments on the changed proce- dures Download a sample at https://spder.web. irs.gov/imd/authors/clear.aspx PDF File The comment feature within Adobe Acrobat. The menu selection Tools → Comment and Markup has tools to add sticky notes, make text edits, and highlight text. XML File The Track Changes and Comment features in the XML editor.
Note: If identiﬁed, reviewers must follow the comment method requested by the IRM author for that respective clearance.

Form 2061 IMD Electronic Clearance Tool a. Select the review assess- ment box in block 13b. b. Sign block 13c. c. Include any comments on the form or other feedback document. d. Return the signed form and any comments to the origi- nator or requester. a. Select the Add Assessment button. b. Select the appropriate as- sessment and Sign button. c. Include or attach comments within the tool. d. The author/creator of the clearance request receives a systemically generated email notifying them of the review- er’s assessment and comments (if any).

) If you discover PII or FTI when reviewing the IRM or after it is published, mediately report it in accordance with IRM
)b. A prompt report decreases possible use of the information to perpetrate identity theft or other forms of harm. (

) Take the following actions immediately : a. Report the breach to your manager, the IRM author, their manager, and their business unit IMD coordinator. They will work with SPDER to revise the IRM and remove content from the IRS electronic sources. b. Contact SPDER at SPDER@irs.gov . c. Report the breach to the Office of Privacy, Governmental Liaison and closure (PGLD) Incident Management Office (IM) using the PII Breach Reporting Form at https://etrak
web.irs.gov/etrak-privacy/page.request. do?page=page.ﬁnal
. Call
if you have any problems with the online form or any questions about completing the online form. (
) See IRM
, Reporting Losses, Thefts and Disclosures, for more infor- mation on reporting inadvertent unauthorized disclosures of PII or FTI.

a. If the author agrees to the suggested changes, the author revises the IRM and forwards the revised wording or revised IRM to prevent any understanding. b. If the reviewer does not respond within the requested clearance date, see IRM

) If substantially revising the IRM during the clearance process, forward the revised IRM to the offices affected by the changes, identifying the changed content. The additional time frame for review must be at least ﬁve business days but not more than
business days. (

) In rare situations where the agreed upon changes require a prolonged time revise, the program executive may approve publishing the IRM without delay. The author must notify the reviewer of the delay to incorporate the agreed upon changes. Once the author incorporates the agreed upon into the IRM, the author clears and republishes the IRM. a (

) If an identiﬁed reviewer does not respond to a request for clearance within required time frame, there is no requirement to follow-up. Treat the non- response as concurrence to move forward with the clearance process. (
) An author documents a non-response by taking the steps below based on method of clearance: Form
IMD Electronic Clearance Tool Annotate the following in Part III, block

a: a. In the “Name”, write the name of the reviewer or reviewing office. b. In the “Title”, write “No Response Received.” a. Select the No Response button. b. Identify the type of reviewer, their business unit, role, and name. c. Select the Save button. (
) The author considers comments received after the agreed-upon deadline following the procedures in IRM
, Respond to Requested IRM Changes. (
) The author must consider all reviewer comments on substantive content changes. (
) In situations where the reviewer “does not concur” with the changes, the author must contact the reviewer to try and resolve the disagreement. For subsequent concurrences, follow the table below.

) If the reviewer continues to disagree with the changes, the author initiates a conference call between the author, reviewer, management and other key personnel from both offices to discuss the differing views before moving forward on publication of the IRM. Inform the IRM program director of any tinuing disagreement preventing the issuance of IRM guidance to employees engage in a decision or resolution. (

) If the disputing offices are still unable to resolve the disagreement, elevate the issue to the heads of office executives for discussion with the overseeing Deputy Commissioner. (
) The author will document the historical clearance ﬁle to explain the rationale behind any non-agreement and if applicable, any resolution. (
) If, after taking action to resolve the disagreement as described in IRM

, Resolving Disagreements, the reviewing office continues to disagree with the substantive content changes, the originating business unit can proceed with publishing if the head of office (executive responsible for the IRM) agrees they must publish the information to ensure operations continue in an efficient manner and to allow employees to perform their duties without unnecessary delays or incomplete/incorrect guidelines. 1.11.9.10.1(10-01-2021) Approval by Program Director
Note: A Personnel Action Request (PAR) reﬂecting the SES classiﬁcation is equal to an “ES” position in Discovery Directory for the purpose of signing an IMD.
The responsible program director (or above) reviews, signs and approves an IRM after internal, external, specialized reviewers and management review.
Clearing and Approving Internal Management Documents (IMDs) 1.11.9

The responsible program director may designate in writing a designee as authorized approving official to review, sign and approve an IRM on their behalf. The designee must be a supervisory manager with program oversight per Delegation Order
, Authorization to Approve an Internal Management Document (IMD), in IRM
) To document approval, the program director (or designee) completes Part block
b and signs in block
c, of Form
, or within the IMD Electronic Clearance Tool, as the approving official. The signature indicates they approve and authorize the issuance of the new, revised or obsolesced IRM. (
) Program directors may not issue instructions or guidelines that affect areas outside their functional responsibility without appropriate clearance. (
) Designated IRM approvers must also record their name and official title as described below depending on the method of clearance used: Form
IMD Electronic Clearance Tool They must record their name and official title in Part VI, block

a and indicate for whom they are signing on behalf of in the Title text box. See example below. Example: James Pelican, Program Manager, XYZ on behalf of Mary Robin, Program Director, ABC. They must also select Yes, they have authori- zation to approve this document and attach a copy of their authorization. (
) The program director/executive with the authority over all the programs approves and signs on the Form
or in the IMD Electronic Clearance when an IRM affects several program areas. (
) The name on the signatory line on the IRM Manual Transmittal (MT) is the current or acting program director/executive who signed on the Form
in the IMD Electronic Clearance Tool. In the event the documented designee signs on the Form
, or in the IMD Electronic Clearance Tool, the name the current director appears in the MT, not the designee. (
) After the program director (or authorized designee) signs, the author takes following steps depending on the method of clearance used:

The responsible program director may designate in writing a designee as the authorized approving official to review, sign and approve an IRM on their behalf. The designee must be a supervisory manager with program oversight per Delegation Order 1-69, Authorization to Approve an Internal Management Document (IMD), in IRM 1.2.2.2.53.
Program directors may not issue instructions or guidelines that affect areas outside their functional responsibility without appropriate clearance.
Designated IRM approvers must also record their name and official title as described below depending on the method of clearance used:

Form 2061 IMD Electronic Clearance Tool They must record their name and official title in Part VI, block 19a and indicate for whom they are signing on behalf of in the Title text box. See example below. Example: James Pelican, Program Manager, XYZ on behalf of Mary Robin, Program Director, ABC. They must also select Yes, they have authori- zation to approve this document and attach a copy of their authorization.
After the program director (or authorized designee) signs, the author takes the following steps depending on the method of clearance used:

Sends an email to the IRS Historical Research Library at IRMLibrary@irs.gov indicating the IRM published and the clearance records are stored the IMD Electronic Clearance Tool archives. Sends an email to the IRS Historical Research Library at IRMLibrary@irs.gov indicating the IRM is published and the clearance records are stored in the IMD Electronic Clearance Tool archives. In the email specify your business unit and the published IRM section.
) The IRS Historical Research Library preserves the permanent record of changes made to the IRM through the Form

, Document Clearance Record (DCR). An archives page stores the IMD Electronic Clearance Tool clearance records. The information serves to support IRM author inquiries, legal cases, investigations and responses to inquiries and audits from outside offices like the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration (TIGTA) or General Accountability Office (GAO) inquiries.
To contact the library, visit https://oldirm.web.irs.gov/ .
